topic: Property Transactions - Capital Gains and Losses

questions.question: A capital asset is defined as:

options.A: Property used in a trade or business
options.B: All property except specifically excluded items such as inventory and business property

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 1221, a capital asset is all property held by the taxpayer EXCEPT: (1) inventory, (2) depreciable business property, (3) real property used in business, (4) accounts receivable, (5) creative works in hands of creator, and certain other items.
questions.tip: Capital assets = everything EXCEPT the exclusions (inventory, business property, receivables, etc.).

questions.question: A long-term capital gain or loss results from the sale of property held for:

options.B: More than six months

questions.explanation: Long-term capital gain or loss treatment requires a holding period of more than one year. Property held for one year or less produces short-term capital gain or loss. The holding period generally begins the day after acquisition.
questions.tip: Long-term = MORE than 1 year. One year exactly = still short-term.

questions.question: The maximum tax rate on long-term capital gains for most assets is:
questions.explanation: Long-term capital gains are taxed at preferential rates of 0%, 15%, or 20% depending on taxable income. The 0% rate applies to lower brackets, 15% to middle brackets, and 20% to high-income taxpayers (plus potential 3.8% NIIT).
questions.tip: LTCG rates: 0% (low income), 15% (middle), 20% (high income). Plus possible 3.8% NIIT.

questions.question: Short-term capital gains are taxed at:
questions.explanation: Short-term capital gains (property held one year or less) are taxed at ordinary income tax rates, which can be as high as 37%. There is no preferential rate for short-term gains, making the holding period important for tax planning.
questions.tip: Short-term gains = ordinary rates (up to 37%). No preferential treatment.

questions.question: Individual taxpayers can deduct net capital losses against ordinary income up to:
questions.explanation: Net capital losses can offset ordinary income up to $3,000 per year ($1,500 if married filing separately). Any excess capital loss is carried forward indefinitely to future years, retaining its short-term or long-term character.
questions.tip: $3,000 capital loss limit against ordinary income. Excess carries forward forever.

questions.question: Capital losses that exceed the annual deduction limit:

options.B: May be carried back 3 years

questions.explanation: Excess capital losses carry forward indefinitely until fully used. The carryforward retains its character as short-term or long-term. Unlike corporate capital losses, individual capital losses cannot be carried back.
questions.tip: Individual capital losses: carry forward forever (no carryback). Keep ST/LT character.

questions.question: In netting capital gains and losses, gains and losses are first:

options.A: Combined together regardless of holding period
options.B: Netted within their holding period category (ST with ST, LT with LT)
options.C: Short-term gains offset long-term losses first
options.D: Long-term losses always offset short-term gains first

questions.explanation: Capital gains and losses are first netted within holding period categories: short-term gains against short-term losses, and long-term gains against long-term losses. Then, if one category has a net gain and the other a net loss, they are netted against each other.
questions.tip: Net ST together, net LT together, then net the results against each other.

questions.question: Long-term capital gains on collectibles are taxed at a maximum rate of:
questions.explanation: Long-term gains on collectibles (art, antiques, gems, stamps, coins, precious metals, and most coins) are taxed at a maximum rate of 28%, which is higher than the standard 20% maximum for other capital assets.
questions.tip: Collectibles = 28% max rate. Higher than regular LTCG (20% max).

questions.question: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain (depreciation on real property) is taxed at a maximum rate of:
questions.explanation: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain represents straight-line depreciation taken on real property that must be 'recaptured' at a maximum 25% rate when the property is sold, even though the overall gain may qualify as long-term capital gain.
questions.tip: Unrecaptured 1250 = prior straight-line depreciation on real estate = 25% max rate.

questions.question: The wash sale rule disallows a loss if substantially identical securities are purchased within:

options.B: 30 days before or after the sale (61-day window)

questions.explanation: The wash sale rule disallows a loss on sale of securities if substantially identical securities are purchased within 30 days before or 30 days after the sale (a 61-day window centered on the sale date). The disallowed loss is added to the basis of the new shares.
questions.tip: Wash sale: 30 days before + sale date + 30 days after = 61-day danger zone.

questions.question: Losses on sales between related parties are:

options.B: Disallowed entirely
options.D: Deferred until the property is sold to an unrelated party

questions.explanation: Under Section 267, losses on sales or exchanges between related parties are disallowed. However, the disallowed loss can offset gain when the related party subsequently sells to an unrelated party. Related parties include family members and controlled entities.
questions.tip: Related party sale loss = disallowed. But can offset related party's later gain.

questions.question: For property received as a gift, the donee's holding period:

options.A: Begins on the date of the gift
options.B: Includes the donor's holding period if using carryover basis

questions.explanation: When the donee uses carryover basis (donor's basis), the donor's holding period tacks on. However, if the donee uses FMV basis (for loss property sold at a loss), the holding period begins on the date of the gift.
questions.tip: Gift holding period: tacks if using donor's basis; starts new if using FMV basis.

questions.question: Property inherited from a decedent is considered held:

options.A: Short-term regardless of how long the decedent held it
options.B: Long-term regardless of how long the decedent held it
options.C: Based on the decedent's holding period
options.D: For one year from the date of death

questions.explanation: Inherited property is automatically considered held long-term, regardless of how long the decedent held it or how long the beneficiary holds it before sale. This rule applies even if the beneficiary sells the property immediately after inheriting it.
questions.tip: Inherited property = automatic long-term. Sell it the next day and it's still LTCG.

questions.question: A loss on the sale of personal-use property (such as a personal residence) is:

options.B: Deductible as a capital loss

questions.explanation: Losses on sales of personal-use property are not deductible. Only gains on personal-use property are taxable. This asymmetrical treatment encourages converting personal-use property to investment or business use before selling at a loss.
questions.tip: Personal asset gains = taxable. Personal asset losses = NOT deductible. Unfair but true.

questions.question: The Section 121 home sale exclusion allows single taxpayers to exclude up to:

options.B: $250,000 of gain

questions.explanation: Section 121 allows exclusion of up to $250,000 of gain ($500,000 for married filing jointly) on the sale of a principal residence. The taxpayer must have owned and used the home as a principal residence for at least 2 of the 5 years before sale.
questions.tip: Section 121: $250K single, $500K MFJ. Must own and use 2 of 5 years.

questions.question: When securities become worthless, the loss is treated as occurring on:

options.A: The date the company filed for bankruptcy
options.B: The date the stock exchange delisted the stock
options.C: The last day of the taxable year in which the securities became worthless
options.D: The date the taxpayer determines they are worthless

questions.explanation: Worthless securities are treated as sold on the last day of the tax year in which they become worthless. This deemed sale date affects the holding period determination (short-term vs. long-term) for the resulting capital loss.
questions.tip: Worthless securities: deemed sold 12/31 of year they become worthless. Affects holding period.

questions.question: Under Section 1202, gain on qualified small business stock (QSBS) held more than 5 years may be excluded up to:

options.B: 75% of gain
options.C: 100% of gain (for stock acquired after September 27, 2010)
options.D: There is no exclusion for QSBS

questions.explanation: For QSBS acquired after September 27, 2010 and held more than 5 years, 100% of gain may be excluded (up to the greater of $10 million or 10× basis). Earlier acquisition dates have 50% or 75% exclusion rates.
questions.tip: QSBS post-9/27/2010: 100% exclusion if held 5+ years. Max $10M or 10× basis.

questions.question: The 3.8% Net Investment Income Tax applies to capital gains when:

options.B: MAGI exceeds threshold amounts ($200,000 single, $250,000 MFJ)
options.C: All capital gains regardless of income

questions.explanation: The 3.8% NIIT applies to net investment income (including capital gains) for taxpayers with modified AGI exceeding $200,000 (single) or $250,000 (MFJ). The tax is on the lesser of NII or the excess of MAGI over the threshold.
questions.tip: NIIT: 3.8% on investment income if MAGI exceeds $200K single / $250K MFJ.

questions.question: Under the installment method, gain is recognized:

options.A: Entirely in the year of sale
options.B: Proportionally as payments are received
options.C: Only when all payments are received

questions.explanation: The installment method recognizes gain proportionally as payments are received. Each payment is split between return of basis, interest income, and capital gain based on the gross profit percentage. Taxpayers may elect out to recognize all gain immediately.
questions.tip: Installment sale: recognize gain as payments come in (GP% of each payment).

questions.question: Section 1244 stock allows ordinary loss treatment up to:

options.B: $50,000 ($100,000 for married filing jointly)

questions.explanation: Section 1244 allows individuals to treat losses on qualified small business stock as ordinary losses (rather than capital losses) up to $50,000 per year ($100,000 MFJ). Losses exceeding these limits are capital losses.
questions.tip: Section 1244: $50K ordinary loss ($100K MFJ) on small business stock. Better than capital loss.

questions.question: Corporate capital losses can offset:

options.B: Only capital gains, with unused losses carried back 3 years and forward 5 years
options.D: Only capital gains, with unlimited carryforward

questions.explanation: Unlike individuals, corporations cannot deduct capital losses against ordinary income. Corporate capital losses offset only capital gains. Unused losses may be carried back 3 years and forward 5 years as short-term capital losses.
questions.tip: Corporate capital losses: offset gains only. Carryback 3, carryforward 5.

questions.question: Capital gains invested in a Qualified Opportunity Zone Fund within 180 days:

options.B: Are deferred until the earlier of sale or December 31, 2026

questions.explanation: Capital gains invested in a QOZ Fund within 180 days of the gain event can be deferred until the earlier of sale of the QOZ investment or December 31, 2026. If held 10+ years, gain on the QOZ investment itself may be permanently excluded.
questions.tip: QOZ: defer original gain until 2026 or sale. Hold 10+ years for exclusion on new appreciation.

questions.question: A taxpayer who doesn't meet the 2-year ownership and use test may still qualify for a partial Section 121 exclusion if the sale is due to:

options.B: Change in employment, health, or unforeseen circumstances
options.C: Only a job transfer by employer

questions.explanation: A partial exclusion (prorated based on time qualifying) is available when the sale is due to: (1) change in place of employment, (2) health reasons, or (3) unforeseen circumstances (such as divorce, death, disaster, or job loss).
questions.tip: Partial 121 exclusion: prorate for job change, health, or unforeseen circumstances.

questions.question: Under the straddle rules, when offsetting positions are held, losses are:

options.B: Deferred to the extent of unrealized gain in offsetting positions

questions.explanation: The straddle rules prevent premature loss recognition when a taxpayer holds offsetting positions (positions that substantially reduce risk of loss). Losses on disposition of one position are deferred to the extent of unrealized gain in the offsetting position.
questions.tip: Straddle: can't take loss while holding offsetting gain position. Prevents cherry-picking.

questions.question: A constructive sale occurs when a taxpayer:

options.A: Sells stock and buys it back within 30 days
options.B: Enters into a short sale against the box or certain derivative positions
options.C: Sells stock to a family member

questions.explanation: Section 1259 treats certain transactions as constructive sales that trigger gain recognition: short sales against the box, forward contracts to deliver stock, and other derivative positions that substantially eliminate risk and opportunity for gain.
questions.tip: Constructive sale: lock in gain through derivatives = taxable now. No more deferring.

questions.question: Capital gain distributions from a mutual fund are:

options.B: Treated as long-term capital gain regardless of how long the investor held the fund shares

questions.explanation: Capital gain distributions from mutual funds retain their long-term character to the shareholder, regardless of how long the shareholder held the fund shares. This is reported on Form 1099-DIV and qualified for preferential LTCG rates.
questions.tip: Mutual fund capital gain distribution = LTCG to you, even if you just bought the fund.

questions.question: Under Section 1061, carried interest (profits interest) in an investment partnership requires a holding period of:

options.A: More than 1 year for long-term treatment
options.B: More than 3 years for long-term treatment
options.C: More than 5 years for long-term treatment
options.D: There is no special holding period requirement

questions.explanation: Section 1061 requires a more than 3-year holding period for long-term capital gain treatment on carried interest (also called profits interest or promote) received by fund managers in investment partnerships. The 1-year period still applies to other taxpayers.
questions.tip: Carried interest: 3-year hold required for LTCG (not the normal 1 year).

questions.question: Section 1256 contracts (regulated futures contracts) are subject to:

options.B: Mark-to-market rules with 60% long-term / 40% short-term treatment

questions.explanation: Section 1256 contracts are marked to market at year-end (gain/loss recognized even without sale). Any gain or loss is treated as 60% long-term and 40% short-term capital gain/loss, regardless of actual holding period.
questions.tip: Section 1256 contracts: mark-to-market + 60/40 LTCG/STCG split. Blended rate.

questions.question: The sale of a self-created patent by an individual inventor generally results in:

options.B: Long-term capital gain under Section 1235

questions.explanation: Under Section 1235, the sale of a patent by an individual who created it (or certain related parties) qualifies for long-term capital gain treatment, regardless of the holding period. This is an exception to the rule that self-created assets are not capital assets.
questions.tip: Self-created patent sale = LTCG (Section 1235). Exception to creator rule.

questions.question: Gain on sale of a home used partly for business is:

options.B: Excludable for the residential portion, with depreciation recapture on the business portion
options.D: Excluded only if the business use was less than 10%

questions.explanation: When a home was used partly for business, the Section 121 exclusion can apply to gain on the entire property if the business portion was within the home. However, depreciation claimed on the business portion must be recaptured as ordinary income.
questions.tip: Home office in home: exclusion OK but recapture depreciation. Separate building = no exclusion on that.

questions.question: Under Section 121, gain attributable to 'nonqualified use' periods after 2008:

options.B: Is not eligible for the Section 121 exclusion (prorated)

questions.explanation: Gain attributable to nonqualified use periods after 2008 (when the home was not the principal residence) is not eligible for exclusion. The taxable portion is calculated by prorating based on nonqualified use time versus total ownership time.
questions.tip: Nonqualified use (rental before 2009 exempted): gain prorated = that portion not excludable.

questions.question: Gain or loss on sale of a purchased call option (not exercised) is:

options.B: Capital gain or loss with holding period based on the option itself

questions.explanation: An option is a capital asset. Gain or loss on sale of an option (without exercise) is capital in nature, with the holding period based on how long the option was held. If the option expires worthless, the holder has a capital loss.
questions.tip: Sell option = capital gain/loss. Option holding period applies. Expires = capital loss.

questions.question: When selling shares of stock acquired at different times and prices, the taxpayer may use:

options.B: Specific identification if adequately identified, otherwise FIFO
options.C: Any method the taxpayer chooses each year

questions.explanation: Taxpayers can specifically identify which shares are sold if they adequately identify them at the time of sale. Otherwise, FIFO (first-in, first-out) is the default. Mutual funds may use average cost basis. The method can affect whether gains are short or long-term.
questions.tip: Specific ID shares for best tax result. Otherwise FIFO applies. Mutual funds can average.

questions.conceptTested: Real estate capital gain vs ordinary
questions.question: Gain on sale of real estate held primarily for sale to customers (dealer property) is:

options.B: Ordinary income

questions.explanation: Real estate held primarily for sale to customers in the ordinary course of business (dealer property) produces ordinary income, not capital gain. This is similar to inventory treatment. The determination depends on holding purpose, not the property itself.
questions.tip: Dealer = ordinary income. Investor = capital gain. Same property, different tax treatment.

questions.question: Capital gains from partnerships and S corporations flow through to owners:

options.B: Retaining their character as capital gains
options.C: Only when the owner's interest is sold

questions.explanation: Capital gains from pass-through entities (partnerships, S corps) retain their character when passed to owners. The gain is reported on Schedule K-1 and the owner reports it on their personal return as capital gain, preserving preferential rates.
questions.tip: Pass-through capital gains = still capital gains to owners. Character preserved.
